title: 103_hr429
content: The "Taxpayer Debt Buy-Down Act" designates amounts for the reduction of public debt under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 by adding a new part for the designation of funds. The Taxpayer Debt Buy-Down Act allows individuals to designate up to 10% of their adjusted income tax liability to reduce public debt. This designation must be made when filing tax returns and is separate from any contributions to the Presidential Election Campaign Fund. The Taxpayer Debt Buy-Down Act allows individuals to designate up to 10% of their adjusted income tax liability to reduce public debt for taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. This includes the creation of the Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Taxpayer Debt Buy-Down Act allows individuals to designate up to 10% of their adjusted income tax liability to reduce public debt. This includes the creation of the Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund in the Treasury of the United States, which is used to pay off or buy back federal government obligations included in the public debt. Any obligations paid with funds from the Trust Fund are canceled and retired, and cannot be reissued. The Taxpayer Debt Buy-Down Act establishes the Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund to reduce public debt. The amendments apply to amounts received after the enactment date. Sequestration to reduce public debt is introduced in Part C of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 introduces sequestration measures to reduce public debt. Sequestration equivalent to estimated aggregate amounts designated under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is required within 15 days after Congress adjourns. Each US account shall be reduced by a dollar amount, with exceptions outlined in the legislation. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 mandates sequestration measures to reduce public debt. Accounts of the United States will be reduced by a dollar amount calculated by multiplying the level of budgetary resources by a uniform percentage, with exceptions for certain accounts like Social Security benefits and interest payments. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 mandates sequestration measures to reduce public debt. The Act includes provisions for various funds such as the Bank Insurance Fund, FSLIC Resolution Fund, Savings Association Insurance Fund, credit union share insurance fund, and Resolution Trust Corporation. Amendments to the Act require reports to Congress on income tax designations and sequestration to reduce the public debt. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 mandates sequestration measures to reduce public debt. Amendments to the Act require reports to Congress on income tax designations and sequestration to reduce the public debt, including details on reductions required and sequestration percentages. Final reports must include all information from the public debt taxation designation report required on May 1. The amendments made by this section will not have any effect after the first fiscal year without public debt.
